Question 1: A young boy came to visit his mother admitted to the antenatal ward for her delivery. You are 
the paediatrician on rounds in the adjacent post-natal cubical. His speech was very different 
from a normal child. Out of curiosity, you examine his oral cavity and the following finding is 
seen. What would be the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows an abnormally short lingual frenulum called Ankyloglossia. Ankyloglossia is also called “tongue-tie” due to an abnormally short lingual frenulum that can 
hinder tongue movement. It can interfere with speech or feeding. In such cases, surgical 
correction is indicated. The image below shows tongue tie and the classic W-shaped appearance of the tongue on 
protrusion: Fissured tongue (Option C) (scrotal tongue or lingua plicata) is a benign malformation in which 
numerous small furrows or deep grooves are present on the dorsal surface of the tongue. Food 
particles and debris may become trapped in the fissures, resulting in irritation, inflammation, and 
halitosis. Macroglossia (Option D), or an abnormally large tongue, may be seen in disorders like Down's 
syndrome, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome, Hurler's syndrome, and cretinism.

questions.question:
Question 2: Sirish, a young talented singer failed to make it through the Music Idol audition. Deeply 
affected by this, he drank a full bottle of a drain unclogger. He was rushed to the ER with 
froth in the mouth. Which of the following could be done as the first step in treatment?

options.d: Gag the child to induce emesis

questions.explanation:
358 
Sold by @itachibot The recommended first step in the case of alkali ingestion (most commonly seen with drain 
uncloggers/ house hold cleaning agents) is dilution through the administration of milk or water. Contraindications in a case of caustic (strong acid or alkali) ingestion: • Neutralization • Induced emesis • Gastric lavage

questions.question:
Question 3: Mala, a young student of class 9 accidentally pipettes sulphuric acid while performing 
volumetric analysis in her chemistry lab. Which type of mucosal damage would you expect in 
her?
questions.explanation:
Acid ingestion produces coagulative necrosis. Acid ingestion produces coagulative necrosis and a somewhat protective thick eschar. The amount 
of acidic agents usually ingested is low as they are generally bitter. Alkali ingestion: Most cases (70%) of caustic ingestions are accidental. Drain uncloggers are most 
common as they are tasteless so more is ingested. Alkali ingestion produces liquefactive necrosis.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 48-hours-old boy baby born at 35 weeks of gestation regurgitates the feeds given to him. 
Abdominal examination reveals an airless scaphoid abdomen. A contrast study is performed 
and the findings are as shown below. What is the possible diagnosis?

options.a: Esophageal atresia in TEF type A
options.b: Esophageal atresia in TEF type D
options.c: Esophageal atresia in TEF type C
options.d: Esophageal atresia in TEF type B

questions.explanation:
The defect demonstrated in the contrast study depicts oesophagal atresia (EA). Isolated 
oesophagal atresia falls under tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) type A. Oesophagal atresia is the most common congenital anomaly of the oesophagus, >90% have an 
associated TEF. Plain radiography in the evaluation of respiratory distress might reveal a coiled feeding tube in the 
oesophagal pouch and/or an air-distended stomach, indicating the presence of a coexisting TEF. 
Conversely, pure EA can manifest as an airless scaphoid abdomen. The following classification was given by Gross: 359 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: 350 
Sold by @itachibot A full-term infant with a history of polyhydramnios in utero presents with respiratory distress 
soon after birth. On examination frothing at the mouth is observed. What would be the 
immediate investigation of choice?

options.c: Passing a nasogastric tube with subsequent chest radiography

questions.explanation:
Newborn presenting with the above features is suggestive of a case of TEF with possible 
esophageal atresia. This can be confirmed with a chest X-ray image showing a coiled nasogastric 
tube in the esophageal pouch, as shown in the image below. Indicators of esophageal atresia with or without a tracheo-esophageal fistula (TEF) are a newborn 
presenting with: • Early-onset respiratory distress • Frothing at the mouth and nose • History of polyhydramnios Radiological findings: • Passing a nasogastric tube with subsequent chest radiography will reveal a coiled nasogastric 
tube in the esophageal pouch. • If an air-distended stomach is also present, it indicates the presence of a coexisting TEF. • Pure EA can manifest as an airless scaphoid abdomen.

questions.question:
Question 6: Milind, a young child is brought to you for recurrent respiratory symptoms and dysphagia. 
After ruling out other causes, you suspect a vascular anomaly that could be compressing the 
esophagus to be causing the symptoms. A CECT is done and the findings are as shown below. 
Which of the following vascular anomalies is most likely to cause this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario suggests a diagnosis of dysphagia lusoria, which is caused most likely by 
the aberrant right subclavian artery. The given image suggests the presence of the right aberrant 
subclavian artery. Dysphagia lusoria is dysphagia produced due to extrinsic compression of the oesophagus by a 
developmental vascular anomaly, often an aberrant right subclavian artery or right-sided or 360 
Sold by @itachibot double aortic arch.

questions.question:
Question 7: You are a new intern posted in the department of pediatrics. The lab reports of a newborn 
baby admitted to the SNCU arrive and the ABG report is as below. Which congenital anomaly 351 
Sold by @itachibot would you suspect in such a setting of electrolyte and acid-base imbalance?
questions.explanation:
Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis, an electrolyte and acid-base imbalance 
characteristically seen in congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS). A pH of 7.55 indicates alkalosis and plasma HCO3- is 30 mmol/L, which is in the higher range. 
Both these findings indicate metabolic alkalosis. Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality. 
i.e Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria. • Persistent vomiting results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development 
of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-). • Kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3-. However, loss of sodium 
stimulates the secretion of aldosterone through the RAAS pathway. • The aldosterone causes active reabsorption of sodium in exchange for K+ and H+ ions. • Loss of potassium ions leads to the development of hypokalemia. • Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in aciduria. It is 
called paradoxical aciduria, since the body initially lost H+ ions due to loss of HCl, and instead of 
compensating for that loss, the body is losing more H+ ions through urine. CHPS typically presents with the following: • Non-bilious vomiting, which is progressive, maybe projectile, occurring immediately after a feed, 
usually presents after the 3rd week of age. • As the vomiting continues, a progressive loss of fluid, hydrogen ions, chloride ions, and 
potassium leads to hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria. Hyperbilirubinemia is the most common clinical association of pyloric stenosis, which is also 
known as the icteropyloric syndrome.

Question 9: Savitri, a 3-week-old baby is having bouts of non-bilious projectile vomiting. On examination, 
the child seems lethargic and dehydrated. Abdominal examination reveals visible gastric 
peristalsis. What is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The presence of non-bilious vomiting and visible gastric peristalsis is highly suggestive of 
congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. The investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis is 
ultrasound. CHPS is associated with hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus resulting in constriction 
and obstruction of the gastric outlet. It is common between 3-6 weeks of age. First-born male 
infants are at the highest risk. Infants usually present with projectile, non-bilious vomiting. Clinically, an olive-shaped mass is 
palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium. When the infant is given a test feed, visible 
peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting. The 
characteristic metabolic abnormality is hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis due to recurrent 
vomiting. Ultrasound features: • Double-layered hypertrophic mucosa protrudes into the stomach, creating the so-called ‘Nipple 
sign’ • The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix 
and is sometimes referred to as the ‘cervix sign’ • The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis are a muscle thickness of 4 mm and a pyloric length 
of 16 mm If ultrasound is inconclusive, contrast studies (barium) are performed, which demonstrate • An elongated pyloric channel (string sign), • A bulge of the pyloric muscle into the antrum (shoulder sign), and • Parallel streaks of barium seen in the narrowed channel, producing a “double tract sign.” The image attached below shows the USG findings in CHPS. 362

questions.question:
Question 10: Ashwini, the mother of a young baby is concerned after she noticed straw yellow-colored 
stains in her child's clothing while washing them. She brings the child to you for examination. 
The child has a mildly elevated temperature and the fluid comes out from the umbilicus, 
whenever the child strains. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The diagnosis in the above case is a urachal fistula. The clinical vigentte suggesting straw -yellow 
fluid (suggestive of urine) along with secondary infection (mildly elevated temperature) and 
presence of fluid only on straining are all suggestive of urahcal fistula. The urachus is an embryologic canal connecting the dome of the fetal bladder with the allantois, a 
structure that contributes to the formation of the umbilical cord. In this condition, there is 
continuous urinary drainage from the umbilicus on straining. It usually presents as a tender, 
swollen mass secondary to infection. Diagnosis is made by ultrasonography or computed tomography (CT). Definitive management is surgical resection of the tract. A patent vitellointestinal duct, patent omphalomesenteric duct and bladder diverticulum will 
cause umbilical discharge even in the absence of straining. The discharge in such a case is 
composed of the contents of the intestine (curdy white in colour mostly).

questions.question:
Question 11: On observing the following finding in the X-ray of a baby, what is the most likely diagnosis 
you would suspect?
questions.explanation:
The presence of a “double-bubble” sign on a plain abdominal radiograph is suggestive of a 
diagnosis of duodenal atresia. The double bubble is caused by the distension of stomach and 
proximal duodenum. Duodenal atresia results from failed recanalization of the intestinal lumen during gestation. A 
history of polyhydramnios is present; half of the infants seen with duodenal atresia are premature. 
The hallmark of duodenal obstruction is bilious vomiting without abdominal distention, which is 
usually noted on the 1st day of life. 364 
Sold by @itachibot The initial treatment of infants with duodenal atresia includes nasogastric or orogastric 
decompression and intravenous fluid replacement. The typical surgical repair for duodenal atresia 
is duodenoduodenostomy.

questions.question:
Question 12: An infant was brought to the paediatrician with complaints of vomiting and abdominal 
distention. The parents inform that the baby passes stools that look like currant jelly. On 
ultrasonography, a target sign was observed. Which of the following is not true about this 
condition?

options.a: Rota virus vaccine is not associated with increased risk
options.c: The most common cause is idiopathic
options.d: The most common location is ileocolic region

questions.explanation:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of intussusception and the rotavirus vaccine is associated with 
an increased risk, albeit only a slightly increased risk Intussusception occurs when a portion of the alimentary tract is telescoped into an adjacent 
segment. The most common location of intussusception is ileocolic. Ileoileal location is seen 
postoperatively and in Henoch–Schönlein Purpura. 90% of cases of intussusception in children are idiopathic in nature. It can be seen in infants 
during the weaning period following the introduction of new food, vaccination, or upper 
respiratory tract infection. The currently approved rotavirus vaccines are associated with a slightly 
increased risk of intussusception. Lead points are more common in children older than 2 years of age and can cause recurrent 
intussusception. Some recognizable lead points are as follows: enlarged submucosal Peyer's 
patch, Meckel's diverticulum, intestinal polyp, neurofibroma, intestinal duplication cysts, 
leiomyomas, hamartomas, anastomotic suture line, enterostomy tube, hemangioma, or malignant 
conditions such as lymphoma or Kaposi sarcoma.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 4-year-old child is admitted to your unit with recurrent pancreatitis. Which of the following 
developmental anomalies is likely to be associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Pancreas divisum is the most common congenital anomaly associated with recurrent pancreatitis. 
It is also the most common pancreatic developmental anomaly. It results from the failure of fusion of the dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds, due to which, the 
tail, body, and part of the head of the pancreas drain through the small accessory duct of Santorini 
rather than the main duct of Wirsung. It may be associated with recurrent pancreatitis.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 7-year-old boy was playing football with his friends during the PET classes. Suddenly he 
complained of severe abdominal pain and he is rushed to the pediatric ER. An erect X-ray 
scan of the abdomen showed the following picture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Sigmoid volvulus is the most likely diagnosis. It occurs when the sigmoid colon twists on the 
sigmoid mesocolon. It is a cause of large bowel obstruction.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 12-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset severe 
generalised abdominal pain associated with fever, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea. On 354 
Sold by @itachibot examination, his abdomen is tense with generalised tenderness, guarding and McBurnys 
tenderness is present. No bowel sounds are present. What is the best diagnostic investigation 
in this child?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute appendicitis. Ultrasound is the best diagnostic 
investigation in the evaluation of acute appendicitis and has demonstrated >90% sensitivity 
and specificity. 365 
Sold by @itachibot The advantages of ultrasound include its easy availability, rapid method, low cost, and freedom 
from ionizing radiation. The ultrasound criteria for appendicitis include the following: • Wall thickness 6 mm • Luminal distention • Lack of compressibility • A complex mass in the right lower quadrant • Or an appendicolith Image: Ultrasound showing evidence of appendicitis

questions.question:
Question 16: Aaradhana, a 14-year-old girl is feeling embarrassed as she has to often rush to the restroom 
during school hours. Her friends also make fun of her as she blushes frequently for no reason. 
She was later diagnosed with an appendicular tumour. Labs revealed low levels of niacin with 
the tumour being positive for synaptophysin. Which of the following biochemical moieties 
can be demonstrated in the patient's urine sample?
questions.explanation:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of a carcinoid tumour. Elevated levels of urinary 5-hydroxy 
indole acetic acid (5-HIAA) can be seen in this condition. The carcinoid tumours are neuroendocrine tumours arising from enterochromaffin cells that can 
occur anywhere in the GIT. In children, they are most commonly seen in the appendix. A 
carcinoid tumour with metastasis to the liver is likely to produce carcinoid syndrome. The tumour 
elaborates serotonin, 5-HT, and histamine, which produce flushing (frequent blushing), watery 
diarrhoea, bronchoconstriction, and right heart failure. Carcinoid syndrome can cause secondary niacin deficiency as they consume and divert the 
tryptophan NAD+ pathway to cause the overproduction of serotonin. Thus, these patients can also 
have pellagra like features. The diagnosis can be confirmed by elevated levels of urinary 5-HIAA. 366 
Sold by @itachibot The image attached above demonstrates islands and nests of uniform cells with scant, pink 
granular cytoplasm and salt and pepper chromatin. Synaptophysin is typically positive in carcinoid tumors. Treatment: Essentially surgical. Medical management includes the administration of somatostatin 
analogues (octreotide). • Small tumours (<1 cm in size) are treated by appendectomy. • Larger tumours (>2 cm in size) require further bowel resection.

questions.question:
Question 17: A 14-year-old boy presents with recurrent colicky abdominal pain and melena. On 
examination, you note the following lesions in the buccal mucosa. You suspect Peutz-Jeghers 
syndrome and advice for the endoscopic investigation to look for polyps. In which part of the 
intestine would you expect to find maximum polyps? 355 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The hamartomatous polyps in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome are seen in order of prevalence: 
Jejunum > ileum > duodenum > colonic or gastric.

questions.question:
Question 18: A full-term neonate was found to have distention of the abdomen. He also passed his 
meconium late and based on further workup was later diagnosed with Hirschsprung disease. 
Which of the following conditions is least likely to be found in association with this?
questions.explanation:
Hirschsprung disease is not associated with Edward syndrome (trisomy 18). It is associated with: • Trisomy 21/ Downs syndrome • Joubert syndrome • Smith–Lemli–Opitz syndrome • Shah–Waardenburg syndrome • Multiple endocrine neoplasia 2 syndrome • Neurofibromatosis (Von recklinghausen disease) 367 
Sold by @itachibot • Neuroblastoma • Urogenital or cardiovascular abnormalities. Hirschsprung disease or congenital aganglionic colon is characterized by the absence of ganglion 
cells in the submucosal and myenteric plexus. It is more common in males. Risk factors include 
Down's syndrome and RET oncogene. The imaging modality of choice in Hirschsprung's disease is a contrast radiograph 
with barium or gastrograffin enema (image shown above). The most important film is a lateral or oblique view of the rectum during slow filling. It typically 
shows a low bowel obstruction. The rectum is seen as a narrow tube and a cone-shaped transition 
zone, seen proximal to the dilated ganglionated bowel. A rectal suction biopsy is a gold standard for the diagnosis and operative intervention is the 
definitive treatment. Definitive surgeries for Hirschsprung disease are as follows: • Swenson procedure, where aganglionic bowel is removed and a coloanal anastomosis is 
performed. • Duhamel procedure, where the aganglionic rectal stump is left in place and the ganglionated 
normal colon is pulled posterior. • Soave procedure: In this procedure, endorectal mucosal dissection is done within the aganglionic 
distal rectum and then the ganglionated normal colon is pulled through the remnant muscular 
cuff, and a coloanal anastomosis is performed. NOTE: In the fetus, migration of the neuronal crest tissues to form myenteric plexus and ganglion cells is 
completed by the 24th week of life. If interrupted in migration, it results in Hirschsprung disease.

questions.question:
Question 19: A neonate is being evaluated in the nursery for failure to pass meconium in the last 48 hours. 
Physical examination reveals abdominal distension and an anal dimple. Wangenstein's 
invertogram shows a low lying defect. Further evaluation reveals the presence of vertebral 
and renal deformities. Which of the following conditions is least likely to be seen in this 
child?
questions.explanation:
368 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical vignette is suggestive of imperforate anus in a neonate with VACTERL 
association (presence of vertebral and renal anomalies in addition to the anal 
atresia). Lymphedema is not a component of VACTERL syndrome. VACTERL association is a disorder that affects many-body systems. People diagnosed 
with VACTERL association typically have at least three of the following characteristic features. Components of VACTERL association: • Vertebral • Anorectal • Cardiac • Tracheal • Esophageal • Renal • Radial • Limb anomalies Anorectal malformations: • It occurs due to the post-allantoic gut with the proctodaeum. • Newborns classically present with inability to pass meconium within 48 hours, abdominal 
distention, intestinal obstruction, improper anal dimple, and sometimes with complaints of 
passing meconium per urethra. Wingspread Classification: • Low - Below the level of the pelvic floor (puborectalis). • Intermediate - Occurs at the level of the puborectalis with or without fistula. • High - Anorectal agenesis, rectal atresia. Investigations: • Wangenstein's invertogram is done 6-12 hours after birth with a metal coin strapped to the 
presumed site of the anus. The X-ray taken is used to measure and classify the deformity. • USG abdomen • Imaging to evacuate associated abnormalities Treatment is surgical.

questions.question:
Question 20: You notice a 5-year-old boy walking very differently in an orphanage. On probing further the 
guardian informs that he has a history of frequently soiling his pants. On examination, you 
find a mass protruding through his anus and a diagnosis of rectal prolapse is made. Which of 
the following would be the most likely cause for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
In this case, the most likely cause of rectal prolapse would be Trichuriasis. It is common in poor 
rural communities with inadequate sanitary facilities and soil contaminated with human or 
animal feces. The highest infection rate occurs among children between 5-15 years. 369 
Sold by @itachibot Clinical manifestations include chronic dysentery, anemia, poor growth, and developmental 
deficits. In heavy infections, adult worms can extend throughout the colon down to the rectum. 
Over time, inflammation of the rectum causes tenesmus leading to prolapse. Other options: Pertussis would present with cough, low-grade fever, and sneezing. Increased abdominal pressure 
due to the persistent cough could cause a prolapse. Chronic constipation is unlikely as the child has a history of frequently soiling his pants, 
suggestive of dysentery. Cystic fibrosis would manifest much earlier in life with respiratory symptoms like recurrent 
pneumonia. These children have exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, causing protein and fat 
malabsorption. This leads to bulky, greasy stools and eventually a prolapse if untreated. 370 
Sold by @itachibot Medical GI disorders
